dt: {bc}to capture or seize especially after pursuit
{bc}to take or entangle in or as if in a snare

dt.t: He started to say the wrong thing but quickly {it}caught{/it} himself.
He {it}caught{/it} her by the arm as she tripped.

dt: {bc}to grasp and hold on to (something in motion)
{bc}to respond sympathetically to the point of being imbued {dx_def}see {dxt|imbue||2}{/dx_def} with

dt.t: He {wi}caught{/wi} a bullet in the leg.

dt: {bc}to take or get usually momentarily or quickly

dt.t: The glint of the gold in each case {phrase}caught my eye{/phrase}, you see.
The pitch {wi}caught{/wi} him in the back.

dt: {bc}to grasp by the senses or the mind
{bc}to apprehend and fix by artistic means

dt.t: The new portrait {wi}catches{/wi} her likeness perfectly.
{it}caught{/it} the last part of the concert

dt: {bc}to serve as a {a_link|catcher} for in baseball
{bc}to grasp hastily or try to grasp

dt.t: The kite {it}caught{/it} in the tree branches.

dt: {bc}to play the position of catcher on a baseball team
{bc}to fail to raise an oar clear of the water on recovery of a stroke
{bc}to find or see at any time

dt.t: wouldn't be {it}caught dead{/it} in that shirt

dt: {bc}to increase greatly in scope, popularity, interest, or effectiveness

dt.t: He'll really {wi}catch it{/wi} from the boss if he's late again.

dt: {bc}to rest long enough to restore normal breathing
{bc}to rest after a period of intense activity

pt: {sc}catch{/sc} {sc}capture{/sc} {sc}trap{/sc} {sc}snare{/sc} {sc}entrap{/sc} {sc}ensnare{/sc} {sc}bag{/sc} mean to come to possess or control by or as if by seizing. {sc}catch{/sc} implies the seizing of something in motion or in flight or in hiding.

pt.t: {it}caught{/it} the dog as it ran by

pt: {sc}capture{/sc} suggests taking by overcoming resistance or difficulty.

{sc}trap{/sc} {sc}snare{/sc} {sc}entrap{/sc} {sc}ensnare{/sc} imply seizing by some device that holds the one caught at the mercy of the captor. {sc}trap{/sc} and {sc}snare{/sc} apply more commonly to physical seizing.

pt.t: {it}entrapped{/it} the witness with a trick question

pt: {sc}bag{/sc} implies shooting down a fleeing or distant prey.

et: Middle English {it}cacchen{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}cacher, chacher, chacer{/it} to hunt, from Vulgar Latin {it}*captiare{/it}, alteration of Latin {it}captare{/it} to chase, frequentative of {it}capere{/it} to take {ma}{mat|heave:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to capture or seize especially after pursuit
to take or entangle in or as if in a snare

dt: {bc}the total quantity caught at one time
{bc}a game in which a ball is thrown and caught
{bc}one worth catching especially as a spouse
{bc}a round for three or more unaccompanied usually male voices often with suggestive or obscene lyrics
{bc}a momentary audible break in the voice or breath

shortdef: something caught; especially : the total quantity caught at one time
the act, action, or fact of catching
a game in which a ball is thrown and caught

cxs.cxl: past tense and past participle of

dt.t: a {wi}catch-as-catch-can{/wi} system that relies on borrowed judges

shortdef: using any available means or method : hit-or-miss

dt.t: didn't {it}catch on{/it} to what was going on

shortdef: to become aware : learn; also : understand
to detect in error or wrongdoing
to take unawares or by surprise

dt: {bc}a problematic situation for which the only solution is denied by a circumstance inherent in the problem or by a rule

dt.t: the show-business {wi}catch-22{/wi}—no work unless you have an agent, no agent unless you've worked

dt: {bc}the circumstance or rule that denies a solution
{bc}a measure or policy whose effect is the opposite of what was intended
{bc}a situation presenting two equally undesirable alternatives
{bc}a hidden difficulty or means of entrapment {bc}{sx|catch||}

et: from {it}Catch-22{/it}, paradoxical rule in the novel {it}Catch-22{/it} (1961) by Joseph Heller
shortdef: a problematic situation for which the only solution is denied by a circumstance inherent in the problem or by a rule; also : the circumstance or rule that denies a solution
an illogical, unreasonable, or senseless situation
a measure or policy whose effect is the opposite of what was intended

dt: {bc}intended to catch up to a theoretical norm or a competitor's accomplishments

shortdef: intended to catch up to a theoretical norm or a competitor's accomplishments

dt: {bc}the act or fact of catching up or trying to catch up (as with a norm or competitor)

shortdef: the act or fact of catching up or trying to catch up (as with a norm or competitor); also : an increase intended to achieve catch-up

dt.t: the thief {it}caught{/it} the purse {it}up{/it} and ran
education has been {it}caught up{/it} in a stultifying mythology
the … public was {it}caught up{/it} in the car's magic

dt: {bc}to travel fast enough to overtake an advance party

dt.t: The soldier ran to {it}catch up{/it} with his unit.

dt: {bc}to reach a state of parity {dx_def}see {dxt|parity||1}{/dx_def} or of being able to cope

dt.t: students who miss class have difficulty {it}catching up{/it}

dt: {bc}to bring about arrest for illicit activities

dt.t: the police {it}caught up{/it} with the thieves

dt: {bc}to complete or compensate {dx_def}see {dxt|compensate||1}{/dx_def} for something belatedly
